reviewText:
How do I even start reviewing Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance? I think I'll start by telling about something that happened earlier today while I was playing a multiplayer match, an experience that quite well describes several of the qualities of this game. It was quite late into the game, about 30-40 min in and everyone had grown quite powerful. My Armored Command Unit, your most important unit that you use to build your whole army and whose death means you're out of the game in most cases, was under heavy attack from a swarm of Gunships and a Heavy Artillery Installation firing away from the other side of the map. I managed to bring my fighter planes in to take care of the enemy Gunships but the ACU was really low on health, another devastating artillery shell was incomming and if it hit I would be out of the game. The shell was going straight for it's target, I was going to lose. But I did not, straight above the ACU the shell hit an unfortunate fighter passing above and destroyed it. An artillery shell from the other side of the map hit a ridiculously small and fast moving fighter plane, I could hardly believe my eyes.

There is an unbelievable attention to detail in this game, every projectile is calculated individually which adds great tactical depth. Good micro and smart use of the lay of the land can have a significant effect on the outcome of a skirmish as shots might miss,  impact hills, rocks or units they where not intended for. This combined with the games truly epic scale brings one of the game's few minor drawbacks, seven years after release even the fastest computers have to slow down when literally thousands of futuristic aircraft clash.

The scale is another thing worth mentioning, the size of the maps range from quite small 5x5km maps to the enomous 81x81km battlefields that it take several minutes for even the fastest units to cross. So no matter if you want to wage war for hours against 7 opponents or if you're interested in intense StarCraft styled matches Forged Alliance will provide.
There is also a great variety of units, from small land scouts that take seconds to build to colossal experimental units that could take hours for a single engineer to construct but are able to singlehandly defeat huge armies. The balance between units is good, all four factions are viable and almost all units fill some role during some part of the game without any unit standing out as particularly overpowered which is quite impressive as there are hundreds of them.

To summarize, this game is a polished gem. The gameplay, both single- and multiplayer, is great, the design is amazing, the sands of time hardly seem to affect the game at all and the replay value is close to infinite. I'm a huge fan of real-time strategy games and I honestly believe that Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is the apex of the genre.

*Strategic Launch detected*
*Watches helplessly as 72 missiles slowly approach*
*Teleports into enemy base as a final stand, dies but causes a nuclear reaction*

Forgive the lack of hours put into the game - I've put hundreds, if not thousands into the game, but steam hasn't tracked my progress due to using an external program known as 'Forged Alliance Forever', aka FAF. I'll go into why shortly.

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is, by far, the best SupCom game around. In fact, it is one of the best, if not THE best stratergy game around. It has just about everything you can imagine it it, ranging from tiny robotic units the size of houses to huge megabots that'd dwarf entire cities.

The game is very different from other stratergy games, which for some can be it's downfall, whilst others just an incentive to play. It plays on a huge scale. Or on a small scale, varying from map to map. If you have a good processor (which I sadly do not), you can have massive battles consisting of thousands of units - and oh my, such battles are always glorious.

Maps also vary in size, some being a few kilometers squared, whilst others are much, much bigger (forgive me, but I can't actually pull the max map size out of my brain at this moment for some reason).

The game has and supports naval, air and land warfare. It has and supports stealth based warfare as well as 'conventional' warfare, fought between huge armies. It has end-game weaponry that can be disabled via options or left enabled at will, such as nuclear weaponry, heavy artillery, certain experimentals such as experimental artillery - so you've got a turtle against you and that stuff is enabled? No problem! Turn them into the wastes of the Fallout series.

I cannot stress how good this game is. It truely is a masterpiece, and though graphically dated, you really won't notice the graphics half the time because you won't exactly be zoomed in close, or the sheer amount of units moving around will distract you from the low resolution and lowish poly models.

But with the age of the game comes performance issues. You really need a good processor to handle this game with lots of players - 1v1 with 2000 units active at one time is generally not an issue (at least with people with processors like mine, and AMD FX 4100), but larger battles consisting of 2-6 players will result in slowdowns so the user with the weakest processor may catch up.

Overall I recommend this game. I really, really recommend this game. If you like RTS games - get it.

*NOTE*

This game is heavily multiplayer orientated. You can play via steam through skirmish modes and campain, but there are issues (or so I've been told) with multiplayer within the game after purchase. AFAIK you need to use applications like hamachi to play.

So most people will use FAF - Forged Alliance Forever. FAF is a lobby system that allows downloading of custom maps and a large selection of mods on the fly, without fafing with applications like hamachi which have potential security issues.

The game is awesome on multiplayer. There are many different ways to play this game - I myself and those I play with play this game at an extremely slow pace, with games ranging from thirty minutes to many hours in length. This is unusual, but fun and perfectly playable. You can literally play it how *you* want to play it, given that you play with others with the same view.

Or you can go competitive - competitive games are fast, quick and require quick thinking. Or you can play something in between - whatever suits your needs or tastes.

The sun rises on the vast installation you've created.  The morning dew glistens on the grass as air patrols soar overhead.  In the distance, you can hear a column of tanks rolling slowly across the valley.  You can hear birds joyfully singing their song...but the serenity of the morning is ruptured by an explosion not ten meters from where you are.  You look into the distance and see the largest mass of armored vehicles you've ever seen.  Mobile artillery blasts away at your fortifications as the once-distant column of tanks wheels about and comes to engage the new-found threat.  Turrets on the edge of the compound blast away at the enemy as shells rain down from a distance.  You turn to face the direction from which they came just to see the artillery platforms fly apart in a fiery explosion as a small wing of bombers, dodging flak, comes in and drops its payload.  You stand in awe at the combat unfolding before your eyes.

...and you smile, because this is the best $15 you've ever spent.

11/10, no game I've ever played has been able to even come close to the greatness of this work of art.  FA will always hold a special place in my game library as the first RTS I ever played and did not get angry at.  To this day you will not find another game of such caliber.  Don't even try SupCom2, go straight for the gold, and get FA.  If you don't like it, it's not the game, it's you.  Nobody can hate perfection.  This, ladies and gentlemen, is perfection.

This is a significant upgrade to the SupCom engine, making everything appear much more polished and smoother, especially with fog of war. Along with balance changes and new units, it's like a whole new game, rather than an expansion. My favorite part of this game is how it offers a mesmerising view of a futuristic battlefield. How it allows you to zoom up, watch individual parts of an unit move and fire true projectiles. That might not seem to be not that special, but the level of amusement I get when I see projectiles hit things they're not supposed to hit is goofy high. I can spend hours zoomed in just to watch the animations of units, even small things like energy storage growing taller as more energy is stored, and how engineers tilt their wheels to float on the water. I wish every game had strategic zoom like this game, with such polished visuals.

The user interface is still rather basic, but much improved over the original, giving you much more space to see the battlefield. It requires 3rd party add-ons (UI mods) to allow things such as keybind remapping, to display health bars all the time, managing templates easier, and upgrade helpers. I highly recommend at least getting GAZ_UI (I used version 6.1). I had to adjust my build order with the changes that took place, such as starting with a factory first. It wasn't until FA that I seriously started to look at deciphering all the + and - numbers on everything, and learning how to balance energy income with mass income, depending on what I wanted to build. A lot of reading tooltips, looking at unit stats in the unit database web page, and a bit of math helped me out, which is akin to doing spreadsheets.

This game seems to love Intel processors, or those with great single-thread" performance. Playing on a laptop or AMD CPU will result in some slow-mo action before the end. Even if you have a good CPU

reviewText:
Let it be known that my total number of hours in Steam for this game is misleading. I've played Supcom/Forged alliance since 2008 off and on and spent most of my time on the 1v1 ladder. This review which reflect that time and SupCom's merits as a competitive RTS. I won't touch on campaign (Good but not great) nor the story (just there to get you to the next mission) in any great detail.

Supreme Commander is a game whose origins can be drawn to Total Annihilation and it from the Command and Conquer school of thinking more than the Blizzard school. Units exist outside of the movement speed/attack rate/damage mold that has served those games so well over the years. Total Annihilation's contributions to the genre were twofold: Its scale both in map and unit sizes was unparalleled. Its units also existed in three dimensions. Aircraft didn't hover, rather they made bombing runs, or engaged in dogfights, or VtoL craft swayed back and forth as they unleashed their payload. Long range artillery countered any turtle tactics forcing them out of the comfort zone and the sound design supported the entire package. I dare say that none of those who fell in love to TA have forgotten the first time they heard a Big Bertha fire.

Supreme Commander is the natural evolution of that game but in a bigger and more user friendly package. All of the aforementioned features still exist. Units have weight as they turn and massive units don't feel like smaller ones except they are scaled to be larger. If you have an experimental (a very expensive endgame unit) plan its trajectory carefully because you won't be turning on a dime to get it out of danger.

The in Forged Alliance is simple, unobtrusive, and effective. The hotkey system leaves a lot of be desired and is quite clumsy but there are mods to fix that into something more elegant if that is you inclination. Individual buildings can be upgraded as can your ACU, which acts as the King and Queen in chess melded into one units. Absurdly powerful but also the victory condition.

Perhaps SupCom's greatest innovation is its strategic zoom. One can use to to go from looking at the rivets in a tank to a satellite image of the entire map in a flick of the mousewheel. It cannot be understated the effect this has on gameplay. You can see more, plan more, and execute more complex strategies because of this feature alone.

On release this game was far too demanding for most computers and limited its install base. Now I would say almost any decent machine can run in without much issue. It is worth noting that the initial multiplayer client, GPGnet, was discontinued several years ago. What remains are steam's matchmaking infrastructure, which is about as bare-bones as it gets, and the community built client Forged Alliance Forever ( which can be found here: http://www.faforever.com/ ). I strongly recommend FAF as it is still undergoing balance patches, the client is still be developed, and the greater portion of the game's user base resides there.

This was a long and rambling review that is mostly clouded by nostalgia and a love for what I believe is the most strategic RTS on the market.

TLDR: Recommended

reviewText:
TL: DR- 10/10, literally one of the three best strategy games i've ever played, and probably the best RTS.

This game can have a steep learning curve, and campaign missions may well take you two hours to complete if you go carefully, or twice that if you go full defensive on the hardest difficulty setting, but this just means that there's actually meaning to good base design, and it is incredibly satisfying to build up an impenetrable fortress then create an army that will flatten your opponent... hopefully. Then there's also the option of building so many nuclear launch facilities that you can overwhelm your enemy's missile defense systems and drown them in nuclear fire (for reference, nukes in this game are just about the hardest to obtain in any game i've found, but they're also the most visually spectacular and you actually have cause to fear them)

There is a good variety of options for the skirmish mode, you can put yourself in a cagefight with a trio of AI opponents that cheat just for added difficulty, you can customise some major gamemode settings such as completely disallowing certain units or tech-levels, or you can increase the rate at which everyone gathers resources to speed the game up a bit.

The graphics are very nice, especially considering the number if units you will have running around the map at any given time. the textures don't look that great if you were to zoom all the way in, but if you do that you'll zoom out again to find that OH GOD THE CYBRAN HAD A BUNCH OF STEALTHED MONKEYLORDS OUTSIDE MY BASE AND THEY'RE TRAMPLING MY REACTORS!

However, the place this game really outshines anything else i've played is its interface. you can customise so easily what the map shows you in terms of the range of your anti-air, anti ground, indirect fire, etc, your sonar, radar, omnisensor ranges... it offers you so much information but if you're finding it overwhelming you can just switch it all of with about two clicks.
Unit control is so good in this game, in terms of automation. you can very reasonably set up a factory to produce infinite of a set of units, have air transports pick them up from your base, and airdrop into a different part of the map with no input from the player. this makes managing hundreds (or, with mods, thousands) of units so much eaiser, leaving you to direct your army, navy and airforce, and watch the explosions.

At the time it was considered the best RTS game, ever.  Chris Taylor later left Cavedog to form his own studio and worked on a spiritual successor to his best-selling TA game.

It's hard to describe to today's generation what SupCom was like when it first came out.  It was the first triple-A title that really utilized dual-core (and above) systems;  In an era where you had to force most games to run on a single CPU lest they crash, SupCom adored it, loved it, reveled in it.  It would drive the top-end system into the ground with its rich, lush graphics and absolutely enormous battles.

It's also the first game that I can recall which specifically had built-in support for multi-display.  One monitor could show you the ground fight, and on the second monitor you could either have a different camera view or a scaled-up map view.

There are too many things to list which were innovated in this game.  Here's a by-no-means exhaustive list:

* First game to really show what multi-core computers could do with gigantic 1000+ unit battles.

* First pure simulation grand scale RTS, with no RPG-like dice rolls.  If a mega-gun launches a projectile at you, you can dodge it if your unit is fast enough and you are good enough at microing.  Every missile and bullet is simulated when it leaves the barrel.  This made the game a micro-lover's dream.

* First game to support multi-monitor, allowing you to configure each display as you want.

* First use of a wide-scale camera.  You could zoom all the way out to 30k altitude and view the battle as a series of stategic icons, or zoom all the way in and watch each individual shell land on the enemy.

* First use of zoom at where I'm looking" smart camera.  Seriously

Most units can actually launch projectiles or shells at least 10% further range or so outside of their radar detection range.  Other units which had wider radar detection ranges could be coupled with indirect-fire units to maximize your effectiveness.  Early scout units were always useful because of this.  SupCom was never a case of "build unit X until you win" sort of game

you deal with resources in a producing/consumed sliding scale.  This meant that build order was the king, particularly at the beginning of the game, and you had to be careful with how you spent your resources.  Your factories would never refuse to build a unit if your resource production level was low;  They would just take more and more time.  Conversely, if you over-produced but didn't consume enough, you were likely wasting materials and giving an advantage of the enemy who might not be so frugal.  Because of this, each match is a constant tweaking of your economy.  You had both mass (used for building) and energy (used for powering things) to keep track of.

* Wreckage.  Yeah, it's there just to look cool, but it also contains mass which can be reclaimed.  Build a mega-unit and send it to the enemy base and -- oh no, it dies!  Now, not only did you lose your chance, but you've just given the enemy a huge economy boost.  You really had to think about sending in the heavies, as it was possible to give aid to the enemy just by your failures alone.

* Stealth mechanic which allowed you to coordinate sneak attacks and all kinds of fun assassin-style missions against the opponent.  One of the three factions is geared towards stealth play.  (Cybrans forever!)

* AMAZING control over what your factories and units can do.  Want to have a master factory and 6 others which mirror what it does?  Doable!  Want to have a certain factory to exit a unit and then have it automatically patrol a particular route?  Doable!  Want to edit patrol paths once they are defined?  No problem!  Smart engineer units which automatically assist or reclaim wreckage?  Ayup!

* Adjacency economy boosting system.  Factories placed near power sources get a reduction in their power consumption.  But they also get mass-cost reductions when placed near mass sources.  This meant you were always search for the most optimal building configuration to maximize your economy, usually altered by the terrain.

* Upgradable commander unit.  SupCom had a single powerful hero unit which could be upgraded via research to give it extra abilities.  Most of these abilities were mutually exclusive, so you had to think about what approach you would take.

* Pretty decent single-player campaign that's entertaining and fun to replay as different factions.  It's no Starcraft in that regard but I think it's held up fairly well.

* (Sadly no longer applicable.)  Very active eSports community, with frequent and entertaining matches.  Game supports a built-in replay mechanism which allows you to watch matches with ease.

* Tons of really awesome mods which expanded the life of the game, such as Sorian AI (which fixed the fairly braindead default AI) and Black Ops (adds a ton of new units).

* SupCom:FA adds to the already excellent SupCom by introducing a new single player campaign, new experimental units, all new maps, and a new faction (which admittedly, was kinda broken and way overpowered until the bugs were patched out).

reviewText:
This is hands down the best RTS game that I have ever played. Large scale battles with thousands of units under the command of 2-8 players (12 on some custom made maps). Many maps ranging from 5 square kilometers, all the way up to 81 square kilometers - just shy of 50 square miles! - and yes, they really do feel that large.

Pros:

This game is tons of fun whether you're playing alone or with family and friends
Playing alone is great; playing with friends is pure awesomeness.

Very high attention to even some of the smallest details.
There are tons of moving parts. If you go up close, you can see all the tank treads spinning, as well as multiple parts of legs making coreographed motions to create movement.

If a unit has more than one weapon, each weapon will by physically present on the unit, and each projectile will appear different.

If there is a unit that has a passive ability, for example shielding, or radar jamming, you will see that there is a physical part on the unit that creates this effect. What's better is that it will even resemble the actual building structures that use the same effects, to a certain degree.

One of my favorite examples of the above is the Cyrbran Tech 2 Tactical Missile Defense structure and the Cybran Tech 3 Siege Assault Bot. The T3 Bot has it's own personal Tactical Missile Defense system, and looking at the left shoulder will show a similar structure on it (in this case a shpere on a pillar). It even functions by shooting a small red laser at Tactical Missiles, returning them to sender!

Truly massive scale battles.
Up to 8 teams with up to 1,000 units/structures per team, or up to 8,000 in one game, all at the same time. This unit cap can be increased to 2,000 per team and 16,000 in one game with the Lobby Enhancement Mod. Further more, custom made maps can also increase the number of players to a maximum of 12, making the maximum unit/structure count go to a whopping 24,000!

4 factions with similar yet unique units and buildings
Many units, while similar to one another, can vary so wildyl in combat that they can serve completely different purposes.

One example is the UEF and Cybran battleships. The UEF  battleship's main armaments consist of 3 turrets with 3 cannons per turret. It fires all three cannons per turret at the same time, dealing massive damage. The Cybran battleship's main armaments consist of 2 turrets with 3 cannons per turret. However, it fires only one cannon per turret, resulting in much lower damage, in exchange for much higher rate of fire.

Strong community and many mods
There is still quite a big following playing this game even today. You can find this community on the Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) servers. If I'm not mistaken, downloading the Forged Alliance Forever app will also give you the Sourian AI mod as well as the Lobby Enhancement Mod. Personally, I wouldn't skip these two mods for this game, especially the AI mod if you like to play against computers.

One of my absolute favorite features of FAF is the ability to play the campaign in co-op mode with friends. There are pletny of games being played every day from many players with ranging skill levels. You'll find tournaments and just for fun games alike. You'll also find a nice hand full of custom made maps you can download directly from the Vault in the FAF app.

Cons:

The unit movement can get a little annoying at times
Sometimes they'll get stuck or confused trying to walk around one another, and it can be frustrating, though I find this generally not to be much of an issue.

The campaign is just okay.
You are never forced to try harder to win; you can simply just test yourself on how fast you can do it. You can simply take your time to build up your army before advancing to the next checkpoint.

Playing co-op completely changes the experience for me. I guess I just like playing with friends and family.

This game is highly CPU intensive.
Older and lower tier CPUs simply cannot handle this game on it's maximum scale. Towards the end of matches, and especially longer ones against the computers, you will notice massive slow down in game play. The Sourian AI mod, while also more fun due to being more of a challenge, alleiviates a lot of this issue when compared to standar AI that was programmed into the game. The standard computers tend to build tons, and tons of units and leave them at the base for long periods of time, resulting in less fun, and more CPU usage which results in slower gameplay.

For example, an older rig I used with an AMD FX-6300 played the game just fine with 7 standard AIs, up until the end of the game where it was practically grinding to a halt. It was unplayably slow; roughly 3-4 real time seconds per game second. Now I'm using an Intel i7 4790k with the 7 Sourian AIs and I can easily play games well past the 2 hour mark with 0 slow down, with some head room to spare.

All in all, this game is an absolute blast to play! One of my favorite games that I own.

reviewText:
Where to start? Supreme Commander is in one word: MASSIVE. You can set a cap of 8000 units on the battlefield, so if you have a 1v1, each player can have 4000 units. FOUR-F******-THOUSAND. At 8 players (teams don't have to be fair) each player has a thousand troops. I have seen people compare this game to Starcraft with 200 units at the max per player. Some people like the extreme tactics that game has, this game has them too, except on a bigger scale. Let me show you a quick comparison

Airdrops:
Starcaft: Drop 16 marines in 2 medivacs.
Supreme Commader: Drop 20 units in 1 transport.
Armies
Starcraft: A marine/marauder deathball slaughtering zerglings or a zealot rush
Supreme Commander: A 300 strong army supported by experimentals holds off the main force, as battleships and carriers support the army, then on the over side of the map 5 nuclear subs nuke the enemy base as an airdrop composed of 150 units flanks the main force. (And that is on a 1000 units per team)
Nukes: (I know that it's only a lesser part of Starcraft, but it is quite big in the end game of Supreme Commander)
Starcraft: A Nuke won't destroy the main base building, it's mainly for clearing armies or finishing off bases
Supreme Commander: When you usually send nukes, you send 5 or more. Depending on nuke defences the attack might fail but when it hits, it hits. A nuke will wipe a base.
Defence
Starcraft: SC is about the offensive and manuevering, you defend to hold the army off as a bigger force flanks.
Supreme Commander: If you have ever played Halo Reach, on the desert mission where you need to destroy the AA towers, at the end there is a massive Spire. Imagine that but around the spire there is about 50 gatling guns and AA turrets. Also (most games don't have this) you CAN build WALLS. (I know it's amazing)

While I personally like this feature of this game, some peope disagree. There are NO hard counters. (Well yes, the tech 2  UEF flak turret tank will easily  wipe out tech 2 planes and even take on tech 3 planes. And yes, the experimentals are basically hard counters for everything they can target, and the air vs air planes will SLAUGHTER EVERYONE WHO FLIES.) But mostly a tech 3 robot will not have an advantage over a tech 3 tank or vise verca.  And although all the factions look different and have different units, they are mostly the same. The main differences are: some factions unlock different units earlier. eg the Aeon unlock have a tech 1 attack boat. And the experimentals; each faction has 3 or 4 different experimental units.  The graphics are not Starcraft level, but they are still REALLY good.

I would reccomend getting Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance and Forged Alliance Forever".A free community hub for SC: Forged Alliance

Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is a great RTS game that offers an experience like no other. The battles take place on a huge scale with maps ranging from 5km x 5km to 81km x 81km. The sheer size might sound pretty cool, but then you get into more small scale. Base building in this game mixes micro and multitasking with managing multiple bases at a time. Nearly everything in this game is upgradeable in some way, so you have to manage whats upgrading while managing unit production and income. You have to remember to upgrade your ACU so you get the benefits from it, all while remembering to build defenses and intel bases. Base building in this game is also really awe inspiring. Different buildings get buffs from other buildings, such as the energy generator, energy storage, and mass fabricator. These all affect each other in some beneficial way, stressing the need for a good base lay out heavily. The fact that nukes and artillery shells can hit a plane in flight also amazes me.

This game offers some really awesome experiences and has a real need for a good strategy. Base building gets more and more complex when you're trying to get the most efficient base, and upgrades add more depth and variety to the game. If you're looking for a good, fun, and over all enjoyable game, you're looking at it right now.

Oh dang. In the list of my favorite strategy games this is second. This here is a game of epic proportions. 1000 unit cap? With buildings included, yes. Large maps? Largest one is 81x81km, so yes. Economy? In the form of mass and energy, yes.

A little bit in detail. So, economy is truly fantastic. You build mass extractors on mass deposits and energy generators generally on land. Energy generators (obviously) produce energy. Mass extractors use energy and produce mass. Really basic, but, what makes this economy system great, is that you can use more energy and mass than what you produce. This will start draining your mass and energy storage. If your energy and mass storages go negative, all your building will happen a lot slower. You can build storages near extractors and generators. This will increase not only only storage space, but also production of said generator/extractor. You can also upgrade your mass extractors to get more mass production.

In the beginning of every game, you only start out with your ACU (Armored Command Unit). He can build only the basic base structures and defenses until upgraded. ACU can be upgraded all the way to build tech 3 and experimentals.

There are 4 techs. Tech 1-3 and experimental tech. You start out in tech one, and later upgrade your facilities to produce advanced engineers and advanced units. Then there are experimental units. These units need to be produced on the field like buildings (some experimentals are buildings). Experimentals are mostly HUGE units with loads of firepower. In example, Monkeylord. This spiderbot has AA missiles, torpedoes, personal cloaking and a huge laser put on it. This laser can sweep an entire army in one swoop. Each faction has their own experimentals.

There are 4 factions and they all play a little differend. While other is good in aerial combat, other will be more efficient in naval combat. All factions have their own units and experimentals.

If you're conserned about multiplayer and GP.Net (which was GPG official multiplayer client(?)) that was shutdown a while ago, there is an alternative. You can go to Forged Alliance Forever[www.faforever.com] and join their community. They have their own launcher and everything.

An outstanding RTS that every strategist should buy. A soul succesor to Total Annahilation fans should recongnize the single Commander unit that constructs and attacks.

Graphics & Sound:
The game is great on the eyes although this game was released in 2007 the graphics have aged phenomenally. You will need a beefy rig to run it on the highest setting and even at the lowest settings it still looks great. There are some issues with the engineers (construction units) getting lost between buildings.
The game's sound is pretty good but not the greatest. Miniguns sound like sharp and crisp, artillery have an umph to them, and blasters have a laser feel to them. Some sound effects go on loop or are just lounder than other ones around it. One big gripe is that you will not know where something is being attacked when it is off screen you will only hear explosions and projectiles; no marker showing where. The music on the other hand is pretty good music. It amps up when your are battling or under attack and then goes peaceful when it is calm.

Gameplay:
Now to the nitty gritty of the game, the gameplay. Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is your typical RTS. The 4 factions (UEF, Cybran, Aeon, and the new Seraphim) feel uniquely different but still fall back on the basics of base building. You start with you commander known as an Armored Command Unit (ACU) that can create a base within minutes. There are to harvestable resources in the game, energy and mass. Energy is collected by building generators; while mass is only collected on limited mass points on the maps. Maps come in different sizes and climates. They range from 5km x 5km jungles to 81km x 81km tundras. The smallest maps are great for rush and harrassment tactics. On the flip side the larger maps are focused on artillery and other later game weapons. Speaking of weapons there are tons defense and offense tactics; from point defense to tactical missles to artillery and to the biggest and most expensive the Nuke. Each factions has 3 Tech levels that are upgraded through factories and your ACU. Each tech brings new units and new buildings that pack a bigger punch than the last. In addition to the 3 different tech levels each factions gain a hand full of experimental units that take a lot of resources to build but reck havoc on enemy units once they are completed.

Verdict:
An amazing RTS that deserves more love than it has. I recommend picking it up with a couple of friends. There are endless possibilities that you can play each game and with actually people can be very challenging.

One of my absolute favourites in the RTS genre, this game creates the sense of an actual war with its immense scale and (for its time) very good visuals (still looks pretty good).

4 nations, countless units divided into tiers, a fairly standard for the genre resource collection, and a fresh element (intel gathering) ensures a game with nigh limitless options for strategies, especially on the bigger maps (the largest ones are 80x80km in size, that can give you a rough idea just how big this game is).

The expansion (Forged Alliance) brings in even more units, rebalances for existing ones and some new effects as well as a brand new faction (the Seraphim) that make it well worth the price, not to speak of the fact it's a standalone so you can play it without the original SupCom. The game also has mod support, and there are a few really good ones that were made since the game was released (some are still being updated).

Simply put, a must-have for any RTS fan, few games will be able to bring you a similarly amazing experience such as this one.

Imagine a world dominated by marcos and build orders, and explosions.

Except, with a crapton of robots that obey your every command, and follow it to the very end.

Now time for me to write a wall of text.

The game offers many unique and cool features for RTS players, who will be in awe at what they have at their disposal to throw at the enemy, AND use to control their massive land armies, navies, and air fleets. The game will give you the ability to ferry units, back and forth. You can set a rally point for your factories on the rally beacon, and have the transports continously transport reinforcements to the front, allowing you to re-allocate your attention to something else. Along with being able to have an efficient transportation system, and basically less of a headache to transport armies to the front.

You'll also will be enjoying the beautiful destruction the game will provide for you, the AI will pump out armies usually the same order, but will combine all three forces of air, land, and naval. This may result you in pulling your hair out and getting frustrated as your small patrols are no match for the endless swarms of the Hard AI. However, the AI is very easy to beat once getting  the hang of the game, and pumping out your own swarms, or building experimentals and tier 3 units to combat the AI's late game units. Which can easily change the tide of battle into your favor, and keep your interests on the map secured.

If you don't think land units are your most viable option at the moment, as you need them somewhere else but need to hold a position. Don't be afraid to send a few engineers to set up breastworks and turrets, along with artillery to back them up and your troops. Devastating fire power can also be not delivered via barrel, but through your air squadrons carrying nuclear ordnance to the enemy's main factories, or his commander himself.

Nonetheless, there is ALOT more the game has for you to utilize, and it will give you an enjoyable experience of the RTS genre, and again explosions.

There are SOME balance issues I guess but that can be debated.... like these super mega bad-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• units called experimentals can just rip though a player's base more often then not. The balance is the massive cost of resources and length of time to produce one.

But there are a lot of units. ALl of which can be used in different tactical senarios. For instance, the lowest tired and weakest assult bots can be easily defeated but in a swarm of them air lifted down they can swarm-fire gound and air defenses if done right. Higher tierd units cost more and take longer to produce but 3 tech III bomber jets can do a great deal of crippeling damage if your tactics are sound... moreso then a swarm of gunships.

There is a degree of rock-paper-siscors to the RTS element but there are other factors as well. Tactics, player skill and even terrain play bigger roles then this group of units vs that group. You can zoom out to look at a 5km map and see all your units as small icons or zoom down to look at the legs of one of your smaller units. Tilt the camera around to actually SEE the terrain layout. Putting artillary units behind a small hill can protect them from tanks, for example... well, if the tanks don't flank the hill.

There's a campaign but its ot that good. Fights and maps are fun but playing solo against AI is more fun to me then solo campaign. I owned this for years before I activated it on my steam account I have maybe 300 hours in it? So this is my go-to game when I wanna create an army or robots to blow up other robots. And there's nukes too.

4/5 ...there is a player run client called FAF, or Forged Alliance Forever, that people use to play matches. Some game mod mods are also there as well as a very realistic hand coded AI by fans called Sorian AI. The AI sent me an IM saying I have a present for you..." once before it launched a nuke at me. I give FAF 5/5 but you need a beefy modern PC to handle it well."

I found that Supreme Commander was such a brilliant game when it was first released i played it over and over again non stop (retail copy then not steam for you trolls who have noticed my game hours are not too great) i loved the commander and how things were built, loved the variety of  ground, air and sea units and loved multiplayer with my mates, however things change.

Firstly the fact the game only uses 1 thread of 1 CPU in your system and as a result as the game goes on it piles where your units are where theirs are, shell trajectorys the AI tactics and so on and so forth into 1 thread so it bottlenecks after a period which in turn later on will slow the game down to every game second takes 3 real seconds, you can get the saurion ai patch to fix this somewhat.

Unit AI more specifically YOUR unit AI, you spend the game not fighting the enemy but fighting your units as ground units will happily try and shell the tank that is behind a hill that they cant hit due to said hill in the way whilst being cleaned up by enemy tanks that have decided to come around the hill until they have line of sight, air units that just sit on the ground and when an enemy plane comes into range will just pick up and land somewhere else instead of engaging, usually when they take they are then destroyed by any fighters the enemy choose to bring with them.  Sea units are just like tanks and will try and shell things that are out of sight.

The commander and anyother building unit can build/capture at range however they like to drive right up to your blueprint or enemy structure before attempting to build or capture, sometimes circling the object until they have found a direction they prefer to face.  Build time is important and building quick is important so any seconds you can save is great but when your commander or engineers fuss about getting into position its very frustrating.

Super units are a great thing to build the hardship of your labours, of getting a good economy going to support building such a massive thing, the satisfaction of being able to survive this long to have built such a device and of corse the joy when it is finally complete and the sense of power that runs through you sends a chill up your spine....... but its short lived.  Super units are just as dumb as everything else in your arsenal if not worse i built a monkey lord from the cybran team and sent him off on his merry down the map just as the enemy team (aion) sent up their sacred assualt bot, now the monkey lord has a sweeping red laser which has a greater range than the laser on the assault bot so i though yeeeessss this should not be a problem and promptly told him to attack their assault bot only for him to walk straight by the bot whilst targeting tech 1 tanks of his own choosing stop when he had walked past it out of range of his laser and turn to try and correct this, obviously this was to late cause as soon as he got in range the assault bot had hit him with his laser during the pass and exploded as he stopped then the assault bot promptly cleaned up my base.

Obviosly this game has been out a while so this review comes late but its just a warning to any people looking at getting this for the first time be prepared to be frustrated beyond belief at controlling one of the dumbest AI's ever in a strategy game, i cant be bothered to even try and defend this.

reviewText: It may just be a Windows 10 issue, but I had nearly no end of problems getting this game to even work at all. I went through dozens of potential fixes and eventually had to literally re-code one of the game files in order to get the thing to work. I probably wouldn't let that tint my overall review of the game if I found it more interesting. This game is like the blunt hammer approach to RTS games where you just hurl units at your opponent until they die and that's pretty much all there is to it. There's no research tree or diplomacy or any of that, it feels like the mechanics are straight out of an RTS game from a decade ago, which I guess a lot of people probably like, but I don't find particularly interesting. I've played a few games with friends and they last about an hour and feel extremely unsatifying. Granted, I was always at the lowest end of the totem pole in terms of score and whatnot, but just nothing really felt engaging about this game. There's not a lot of information given about each of the untis and such and some of the descriptions are vague and unhelpful. The resource section of the game feels like it has potential, but is mostly just an annoyance. There's only two resources in the game and it acts like it is a finely tuned machine where you have to be precise about energy consumption and mass use, but it doesn't give an easy way to monitor these things and keep the balance you need, so more often times than not, my time was spent in the high negatives or high positives and just guessing what units I could build or upgrade without tanking my economy. I will probably play some more with friends, but overall I see zero reason to play this game instead of Age of Empires II, a game where everything is laid out for you and gives you an easy way to manage and monitor your resources and units. As a general rule, I grade all RTS games in comparison to AoE2 and if the game can't beat out a game THAT old, I'm not really interested.

reviewText:
Way back when, I chose the dawn of war games over SupCom. Those DoW games got me into the corresponding tabletop hobby, and I couldnt be happier with the people I've met and all the friends I've made from just buying one little game.

A couple days ago, I spotted this on steam and decided to give it a try, see what I would have gotten had I chose this game instead.

Before I go on, let me explain that I have always loved RTS games. DoW, AoE, Stronghold, C&C, etc. So when I saw this game and the massively positive reviews for it, I bought it straight away! It looked awesome, whole armies crushing your enemies underfoot, whats not to like?

The game worked for me,   only one crash while I was in the tutorial. So no problem there.

The problem was, well, the mechanics. I am used to a minimap, when I play againest my competitive friends, the minimap is needed for survival. The tutorial pointed out pretty quick that my screen IS my minimap. Great.

Not only did I keep forgetting about it, its also extremely awkward to use. I kept playing without using it, making it seem to me that I was alone, when in fact there was a huge battle going on around me, and I couldnt see it.

Secondly, there is a STEEP learning curve. The Controls take way too long to learn and master. I consider myself atleast competent when it comes to RTS's, I can normally figure out the controls in a game or two.

With this game? Well, you may notice that I only have TWO hours played on it, and also that I've returned it.

Well, thats because these games take HOURS to play. You can't bang out one game in a hour. Heck no. You have to be willing to SIT THERE and WAIT. Wait for your eco to boost up, wait for your buildings to build, wait for your units to be created.

Each unit has around a 7-10 second timer. Even the weak units. Yes it has a HUGE pop cap of up to 1000, which is awesome. But for one thing.

I can't get any resources. The game wont give you ANYTHING starting out, and resources come in at a TRICKLE. For my first skirmish game after the tutorial, I tried setting it on huge resources or whatever, and it does not have any. You are stuck with the regular resources, which let me tell you, are gone faster then ice placed in the middle of the sahara desert.


I had to use CHEATS. CHEATS. To explore the mechanics of the game more fully.

I am not one of those people who can sit down for 4-5 hours on ONE game.  This game is for you if you like slow paced afternoon-length games. If you cant invest the time and effort it takes to play this game, dont buy it.


I spent two hours with this game. Only played ONE game. And I couldnt even finish it because it got boring using the cheats since it took to long trying to play the game with normal resources and setup.


Poor economy, poor unit build time, confusing map interface,  extremely long length game battles without the resources to easily get said long games off the ground effectively, this is a MASSIVE dissapointment to me.


Buy if your a HARDCORE RTS player who can spend hours in ONE GAME.

If you like RTS' but dont want to invest hours in a single match, or are new to the genre on a whole, or just a casual gamer, SKIP.


When I think of the people who might like this game, I think of a old man in his mid 70s.  It requires ALOT of patience. Kudos to anyone who can sit through it, I sure as h*ll cant.


Its like you build a beautiful mansion, but then don't install plumbing or power, and only use one room out of the whole mansion.


Dissapointed, gave it a chance, glad I chose DoW. Skip if you like anything thats not snail-paced.

10/10 A catergorised review for easy reading

Zoom
The strategic zoom alone is multiple steps ahead of other RTS's which seems insignificant but theres really no going back...

Tech and Research
As with most RTS style games there are technology levels (3 with an experimental level as number 4) with multiple races (4 in this game), then there is an economy stucture based on Mass (harder to aquire) and Energy (easier to build).

Units/Maps
All units (aside from Commanders) are robotic and large in size which helps to accomodate for the large maps. They range from 80km by 80km to 5km by 5km. Unit limits are adjustible but can go up to 1000 without mods

Combat types
Forms of direct combat range from space with satelites (but only ground fire with them), land combat, naval combat (including subermrines) and air combat. commanders are also capable of teleporting to destinations.

Mods etc
The game comes with some mods built in that you can turn on or off as you please. On top of this there is a strong modding community which has made many types of mods and mappacks for the game

Spiritual succesor to Total Annihilatoin they said. Well I agree but there are a couple of things that still make the original TA a better game. For starters SupCom takes a LONG time to get a base up and running at maximum efficiency with multiple factories churning out tanks and bots, and the problem is that the AI immediately begins attacking you fom the start so unless you repel the first rush properly and you are able to repel each subsequent attack on your position, because by the time you have dealt with the first the second is often already on the way, then you are screwed.

The maps are much larger which makes for more epic combat and I must say this is a good thing. You can play with more than 4 players on one map as opposed to TA and that is also good. There are three tech levels instead of two and the ability to customize your commander unit which is also pretty cool but beware that upgrading takes much MUCH more ressources, easily exponential amounts which means if your ressources infrastructures are not ready your facotories will simply stop producing. This is what I had the most trouble with in this game whereas in TA I always got the upper hand on the ressource situation I have a very difficult time maintaining my production in this game because of how expensive good units are. Producing masses of tech one level units is simplky not worht it because a tech two unit can easily outmatch upwards of a dozen tech one units and so on for a tech three unit.

Furthermore on the ressource issue, the AI methodically targets your ressource infrastucture before even targetting defensive turrets at times which simply adds to the trouble of collecting enough ressources to maintain production. This is not a complaint in itself just somkething that adds to my troubles with the game.

All in all this game is very good though if you liked TA just don't expect it to be a revamped reworked version of the 1997 classic because this game has a flavour all of its own. Epic battles await and Nukes are awesome in this game.

If you missed Gas Powered Games' Supreme Commander when it released in February, the new expansion offers quite a few changes. We were big fans of the game when it first came out, but there's no doubt it was one of the most complex, time-consuming RTSes in quite a while, and had an unapologetically steep learning curve. Many lamented that the three factions in the original, the Cybran, Aeon, and UEF, looked and behaved too similarly. And on the surface they do resemble each other, but after hours of playtime, you learn to appreciate the differences and understand how to capitalize and manipulate them to your advantage.\n\nGPG seems to have two main goals with the standalone Forged Alliance expansion: faster action and more diversity. Diversity is inserted primarily with the addition of a fourth faction, the more visually distinct Seraphim. Though they, like the other three, possess similar lower tier units, higher tiers possess more individuality, particularly those of the experimental variety. Accessing these differences between factions, meaning teching up to tier three (T3), requires a different kind of resource production strategy since GPG moved mass fabricators from tier one (T1) to tier two (T2). You have to be much more aware of your extractors this time around, making sure to expand your base of operations across the map until you can start churning out T3 fabricators and power plants, since extractors seem to play a much more vital role in maintaining reasonable resource rates in the early game.

reviewText: In my opinion, Forged Alliance can only be described as one of the best Real-Time RTS games of its type. Despite its age it still looks modern with high graphics settings and the addition of a 4th race to the game expands the gameplay possibility compared to the original. However the best thing about this game is the loyal community that continue support of the game with new updates and balance changes through the Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) Lobby after support for the game ceased. Forged Alliance continues the story where the first game left off, but missteps in trying to improve the gameplay. However, it has an active multiplayer scene anno 2014, many performance improvements and an AI that won't trip over itself trying to get out the door. So if you want to actually play, it is definitely the better choice.

Many of the new units, while interesting, don't really fit into the balance of the game. And are often simply bigger and better versions of previous units, entirely invalidating the old ones. While faction diversity is improved, the new faction is more of an amalgamation of all the best stuff from the other three, and can be considered to be over powered.

Unit speeds in general have been increased, reducing the effective scale of the game. And things are more expensive overall, requiring you to focus more on one thing at a time than building out. The starting resources have been increased massively, reducing your choices in the early game to one structure.

The nuclear missiles have been made worthless by breaking the ability to assist their construction, something you'd expect out of every other unit in the game.
The GUI is said to be improved, but has made many functions of the old one harder to use, or simply omitted them.

None of these things make it a bad game, just not quite as good. The many bugfixes and the fact that people still play it outweigh those things by far.
